#Text=Identify Cold
#Text=Spots in Your Fridge
#Text=Cold spots in your refrigerator can ruin some foods or add on unnecessary thaw time to your meal preparation .
#Text=This is a common problem with refrigerators .
#Text=But by identifying cold spots in your fridge , you can avoid them and the unwanted freezing they cause .
#Text=You can find cold spots through trial and error , or you can more accurately locate them with a thermometer .
#Text=Once you know where they are , you can troubleshoot the problem until it 's fixed .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Finding Cold Spots through Trial and Error
#Text=Gather a notebook and writing utensil .
#Text=The main problem with cold spots is that they 're invisible , which makes them easy to forget .
#Text=Having a notebook and writing utensil handy in the kitchen will give you the opportunity to make a log of freezing .
#Text=You might find it even easier to remember this if you use a magnetic pen/notepad .
#Text=This way , when you look at the fridge , you 'll be reminded about cold spots .
#Text=Your fridge may have a few cold spots .
#Text=To hone in on the location of these , you may want to draw a simple diagram of the shelves of your fridge and mark potential cold spots .
#Text=Track the location of frozen food in your fridge .
#Text=Location is the key element you 'll need to track to find cold spots .
#Text=The location of cold spots is usually consistent , so by tracking frozen food in your notebook , you 'll be identifying cold spots .
#Text=You should observe freezing in your fridge for two weeks for the most accurate cold spot identification .
#Text=Various factors , including the amount of food in your fridge , can influence freezing and give you false results .
#Text=More observations will provide more reliable data .
#Text=Chart your observations to find cold spots .
#Text=Now that you have a log of where food freezes in your fridge , you should be able to easily determine cold spots .
#Text=Areas where food has consistently frozen are where you have cold spots in your fridge .
#Text=Even after finding the cold spots in your fridge , you might still forget where they are located from time to time .
#Text=Mark these spots with a visible piece of tape , like a colored piece of painters tape .
#Text=Using a Thermometer
#Text=Select a suitable thermometer .
#Text=A regular thermometer should work for this method of finding cold spots , but a higher quality one will give the most accurate reading .
#Text=Being able to clearly differentiate between temperatures will make it easier to pinpoint cold spots .
#Text=Avoid touching the temperature gauge of your thermometer with your hands or fingers .
#Text=Oil and heat from your hands can influence the temperature reading .
#Text=Fill multiple glasses with equal amounts of water .
#Text=Use the same kind of glass for each one .
#Text=Different glasses may cool down more or less easily and ruin your results .
#Text=The amount of water in each glass should also be equal .
#Text=Larger amounts of water cool less quickly than smaller amounts .
#Text=Fill enough glasses so that each shelf has at least one in each corner of the shelf and another glass in the middle .
#Text=Insert the glasses in your fridge and wait .
#Text=Generally , one glass per shelf corner and one in the middle of each shelf should be sufficient for identifying cold spots .
#Text=You may have to rearrange items in your fridge to fit the glasses .
#Text=Once the water is inside , wait for approximately one hour .
#Text=You can create a more precise temperature map of your fridge with more glasses .
#Text=Arrange the glasses around the perimeter of shelves and across the middle of the shelves , left to right , front to back .
#Text=Take the temperature of each glass of water .
#Text=Once the time is up , take your thermometer and use it to check the temperature of each glass of water .
#Text=Some glasses will be colder than others .
#Text=These colder glasses are where the cold spots are .
#Text=Troubleshooting Cold Spots
#Text=Position temperature sensitive food away from vents .
#Text=Food directly beneath cooling vents will receive the brunt of the cold , which may cause freezing .
#Text=In most cases , you can find the cold air vent above or to the side of the top shelf .
#Text=Many of these vents will have a slatted or narrow opening through which the cold air passes .
#Text=If you have difficulty identifying the cold air vent in your refrigerator , open the door and feel around potential vent areas with your hand .
#Text=If you feel cold air being emitted , you 've likely found the vent .
#Text=Investigate the freezer settings .
#Text=Your freezer can influence the coldness of your refrigerator , especially for refrigerator models with a freezer at the bottom .
#Text=By raising the temperature of your freezer , you could solve your cold spot problem .
#Text=Be sure not to raise the temperature of your freezer above freezing ( 32째F/0째C ) .
#Text=This can cause bacteria to grow and food to spoil faster than normal .
#Text=Add food to your refrigerator .
#Text=The food in your refrigerator acts like a sponge for the cold air .
#Text=The more food you have in it , the more evenly distributed the cold air will be .
#Text=Keeping your refrigerator more fully stocked could be a simple solution to your fridge 's cold spots .
#Text=This is especially true for the bottom of your fridge , where cold air can build up and cause freezing .
#Text=Make sure the bottom of your fridge is well stocked .
#Text=Contact the manufacturer or a service representative .
#Text=Refrigerators these days are complex pieces of machinery .
#Text=In some situations , there may be a mechanical issue with the inner workings of your refrigerator .
#Text=If this is the case , a service representative or manufacturer assistance may be the best way to resolve the issue .
#Text=The manufacturer information for your refrigerator can usually be found in its user manual .
#Text=If you cannot determine the manufacturer of your fridge , inquire with the retailer that sold it to you to determine this information .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Before contacting a service representative , check the information provided that came with your refrigerator to see if it 's still under warranty .
#Text=A warranty can greatly reduce or even eliminate repair costs .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Raising the temperature of your fridge above of the manufacturer 's recommended settings could cause your food to spoil faster or bacteria to grow .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Finding Cold Spots through Trial and Error
#Text=Notebook
#Text=Writing utensil
#Text=Using a Thermometer
#Text=Drinking glasses ( same kind ; many )
#Text=Thermometer
